addressleaf.section: A Monsieur Monsieur de Sidney chevalier et gouverneur de la ville de Vlissing ne s.

page.lettertext:
fol.208r
S
r
Thomas Bodley to S
r
Robert Sydney
I doe not wonder a whitte at
at maner
of proceeding of my masters of
Zeland.
For
I assure yo
r
L. I did never yet perceave
any harty good will, in any one of this people,
ether towardes her
Ma
tie
or any one of o
r
na-
tion. O
r
good offices, and good cariadge,
bothe towardes this state in general and to-
wardes some in particular, may have forced
some one, or some fewe, to make a shewe at some
time of frindship and good will, but undoub-
tedly in a cause of any moment, yo
w
shall
see them so falter in
e duties of affection, as
a man would hardly credit,
at their plaines
were accompanied, w
t
suche notable cu
n
ing
It is a great while agoe, sins by meanes of
my imploiments, I have noted in their acti
o
s
their badde disposition. And therfore for
my self, w
t
out any jote of respect, to their
favo
rs
or disfavo
rs
, w
at
is fitte to be per-
fourmed for her Ma
ties
service, I doe it roun-
dly and uprightly. And for ought I can
perceave, in regard of their good willes,
I may account as muche upon it, as any
other that is heere of her Ma
ties
ministers.
Their dealing w
t
yo
r
L. was too too
rude and injurious. But w
at
will yow have?
It is not possible to drawe wine out of
vessels full of vineger. In my opinion, it
was greatly requisit,
at yo
w
should write,
as yo
w
did, to
e states of that place, to the
end they might not thinke,
at they walke
fol.208v
invinsible. But I knowe they will answear
yo
w
w
t
courtesie and wordes, and litle to
e
purpose for yo
r
satisfaction. This I can
assure yo
w
,
at there was never no ouverture
of
at exploit to this councel, untill they
heard it had failed. To impart to
yo
r
L. as yo
w
desire by yo
r
letter, my
simple advise, me thinkes,
at for
e better
manifestation of
e wronge d
o
unto yo
w
,
and to her Ma
tie
in yo
r
person, and for yo
r
owne discharge heereafter, it will be needefull
yo
w
should signifie
at abuse to this
Councel
as being appointed by
e Contract to manege
all affaires appertening to these warres, and
to give yo
w
audience to any motion,
at shall
tende to
e service of her Ma
tie
or preserva-
tion of
e place,
at is committed to yo
r
charge.
Yo
r
L. writing to them, to suche effect, as
yo
w
please, if yo
w
send yo
r
letter unto me,
I will acc
o
pany
e deliverie w
t
some verbal
remonstrance. At this very p
nt
,
Count Maurice
is abroade about some ma-
ter of surprise, as we are persuaded, up
o
e towne of
Mastricht:
w
ch
is also att
e
pted
w
t
out
e privitie of this Councel: wherat they
doe disdaine, and purpose, as they say, to
tell him plainely of it.
S
r
Francis Vere
is also w
t
him, and hath imparted nothing
to me: wherat I mervell very muche.
But of this I would say more, if I were
in any place, to c
o
ferre w
t
yo
w
by worde.
fol.209r
For truly, to speake planely, I
a
flatly of
opini
o
,
at continuall soothing, and court
i
g,
and flattering
of some persons
at we knowe, or may knowe
to be alienat in hart fr
o
her Ma
tie
and
e
nation, doth but give them more occasion,
to watche a fitte opportunitie, when their
turne may best be served, to abuse
e good
meaning of her Ma
ties
owne servants, to her
notable prejudice. But
at it is a mater
not fitte for inke and paper, I would
hold you longer w
t
this talke, w
ch
nowe
I leave to yo
r
discretion, and wishe yo
r
self and yo
r
estate
at happe
at yo
r
hart
doth chiefest desire.
Fr
o
e Hage.
10 March 1591.
Yo
r
L. most affectionat and at co
m
aundem
t
. Tho. Bodley.
